speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: If you haue teares, prepare to ſhed them now.
You all do know this Mantle, I remember
The ﬁrſt time euer Cæſar put it on,
’Twas on a Summers Euening in his Tent,
That day he ouercame the Neruij.
Looke, in this place ran Caſſius Dagger through:
See what a rent the enuious Caska made:
Through this, the wel-beloued Brutus ſtabb’d,
And as he pluck’d his curſed Steele away:
Marke how the blood of Cæſar followed it,
As ruſhing out of doores, to be reſolu’d
If Brutus ſo vnkindely knock’d, or no:
For Brutus, as you know, was Cæſars Angel.
Iudge, O you Gods, how deerely Cæſar lou’d him:
This was the moſt vnkindeſt cut of all.
For when the Noble Cæſar ſaw him ſtab,
Ingratitude, more ſtrong then Traitors armes,
Quite vanquiſh’d him: then burſt his Mighty heart,
And in his Mantle, muﬀling vp his face,
Euen at the Baſe of Pompeyes Statue
(Which all the while ran blood) great Cæſar fell.
O what a fall was there, my Countrymen?
Then I, and you, and all of vs fell downe,
Whil’ſt bloody Treaſon ﬂouriſh’d ouer vs.
O now you weepe, and I perceiue you feele
The dint of pitty: Theſe are gracious droppes.
Kinde Soules, what weepe you, when you but behold
Our Cæſars Veſture wounded? Looke you heere,
Heere is Himſelfe, marr’d as you ſee with Traitors.
O pitteous ſpeƈtacle!
O Noble Cæſar!
O wofull day!
O Traitors, Villaines!
O moſt bloody ſight!
We will be reueng’d: Reuenge
About, ſeeke, burne, ﬁre, kill, ſlay,
Let not a Traitor liue.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Stay Country-men.
Peace there, heare the Noble Antony.
Wee’l heare him, wee’l follow him, wee’l dy with
him.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Good Friends, ſweet Friends, let me not ſtirre you vp
To ſuch a ſodaine Flood of Mutiny:
They that haue done this Deede, are honourable.
What priuate greefes they haue, alas I know not,
That made them do it: They are Wiſe, and Honourable,
And will no doubt with Reaſons anſwer you.
I come not (Friends) to ſteale away your hearts,
I am no Orator, as Brutus is:
But (as you know me all) a plaine blunt man
That loue my Friend, and that they know full well,
That gaue me publike leaue to ſpeake of him:
For I haue neyther writ nor words, nor worth,
Aƈtion, nor Vtterance, nor the power of Speech,
To ſtirre mens Blood. I onely ſpeake right on:
I tell you that, which you your ſelues do know,
Shew you ſweet Cæſars wounds, poor poor dum mouths
And bid them ſpeake for me: But were I Brutus,
And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony
Would ruﬀle vp your Spirits, and put a Tongue
In euery Wound of Cæſar, that ſhould moue
The ſtones of Rome, to riſe and Mutiny.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Wee’l Mutiny.
Wee’l burne the houſe of Brutus.
Away then, come, ſeeke the Conſpirators.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Yet heare me Countrymen, yet heare me ſpeake

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Peace hoe, heare Antony, moſt Noble Antony.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why Friends, you go to do you know not what:
Wherein hath Cæſar thus deſeru’d your loues?
Alas you know not, I muſt tell you then:
You haue forgot the Will I told you of.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Moſt true, the Will, let’s ſtay and heare the Wil.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Heere is the Will, and vnder Cæſars Seale:
To euery Roman Citizen he giues,
To euery ſeuerall man, ſeuenty ﬁue Drachmaes.

speech.speaker: 2 Ple.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Cæſar, wee’l reuenge his death.

speech.speaker: 3 Ple.
speech.line: O Royall Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Heare me with patience.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Peace hoe

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Moreouer, he hath left you all his Walkes,
His priuate Arbors, and new-planted Orchards,
On this ſide Tyber, he hath left them you,
And to your heyres for euer: common pleaſures
To walke abroad, and recreate your ſelues.
Heere was a Cæſar: when comes ſuch another?

speech.speaker: 1. Ple.
speech.line: Neuer, neuer: come, away, away:
Wee’l burne his body in the holy place,
And with the Brands ﬁre the Traitors houſes.
Take vp the body.

speech.speaker: 2. Ple.
speech.line: Go fetch ﬁre.

speech.speaker: 3. Ple.
speech.line: Plucke downe Benches.

speech.speaker: 4. Ple.
speech.line: Plucke downe Formes, Windowes, any thing.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Now let it worke: Miſcheefe thou art a-foot,
Take thou what courſe thou wilt.
How now Fellow?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir, Oƈtauius is already come to Rome.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where is hee?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: He and Lepidus are at Cæſars houſe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And thither will I ſtraight, to viſit him:
He comes vpon a wiſh. Fortune is merry,
And in this mood will giue vs any thing.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I heard him ſay, Brutus and Caſſius
Are rid like Madmen through the Gates of Rome.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Belike they had ſome notice of the people
How I had moued them. Bring me to Oƈtauius.

scene.stagedir: Enter Cinna the Poet, and after him the Plebeians.

speech.speaker: Cinna.
speech.line: I dreamt to night, that I did feaſt with Cæſar,
And things vnluckily charge my Fantaſie:
I haue no will to wander foorth of doores,
Yet ſomething leads me foorth.
What is your name?
Whether are you going?
Where do you dwell?
Are you a married man, or a Batchellor?
Anſwer euery man direƈtly.
I, and breefely.
I, and wiſely.
I, and truly, you were beſt.

speech.speaker: Cin.
speech.line: What is my name? Whether am I going? Where
do I dwell? Am I a married man, or a Batchellour? Then
to anſwer euery man, direƈtly and breefely, wiſely and
truly: wiſely I ſay, I am a Batchellor.
That’s as much as to ſay, they are fooles that mar-
rie: you’l beare me a bang for that I feare: proceede di-
reƈtly.

speech.speaker: Cinna.
speech.line: Direƈtly I am going to Cæſars Funerall.
As a Friend, or an Enemy?

speech.speaker: Cinna.
speech.line: As a friend.
That matter is anſwered direƈtly.
For your dwelling: breefely.

speech.speaker: Cinna.
speech.line: Breefely, I dwell by the Capitoll.
Your name ſir, truly.

speech.speaker: Cinna.
speech.line: Truly, my name is Cinna.
Teare him to peeces, hee’s a Conſpirator.

speech.speaker: Cinna.
speech.line: I am Cinna the Poet, I am Cinna the Poet.
Teare him for his bad verſes, teare him for his bad
Verſes.

speech.speaker: Cin.
speech.line: I am not Cinna the Conſpirator.
It is no matter, his name’s Cinna, plucke but his
name out of his heart, and turne him going.
Teare him, tear him; Come Brands hoe, Firebrands:
to Brutus, to Caſſius, burne all. Some to Decius Houſe,
and ſome to Caska’s; ſome to Ligarius: Away, go.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Theſe many then ſhall die, their names are prickt

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Your Brother too muſt dye: conſent you Lepidus?

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: I do conſent.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Pricke him downe Antony.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: Vpon condition Publius ſhall not liue,
Who is your Siſters ſonne, Marke Antony.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: He ſhall not liue; looke, with a ſpot I dam him.
But Lepidus, go you to Cæſars houſe:
Fetch the Will hither, and we ſhall determine
How to cut oﬀ ſome charge in Legacies.

speech.speaker: Lep.
speech.line: What? ſhall I ﬁnde you heere?

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Or heere, or at the Capitoll.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: This is a ſlight vnmeritable man,
Meet to be ſent on Errands: is it ﬁt
The three-fold World diuided, he ſhould ſtand
One of the three to ſhare it?

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: So you thought him,
And tooke his voyce who ſhould be prickt to dye
In our blacke Sentence and Proſcription.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oƈtauius, I haue ſeene more dayes then you,
And though we lay theſe Honours on this man,
To eaſe our ſelues of diuers ſland’rous loads,
He ſhall but beare them, as the Aſſe beares Gold,
To groane and ſwet vnder the Buſineſſe,
Either led or driuen, as we point the way:
And hauing brought our Treaſure, where we will,
Then take we downe his Load, and turne him oﬀ
(Like to the empty Aſſe) to ſhake his eares,
And graze in Commons.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: You may do your will:
But hee’s a tried, and valiant Souldier.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: So is my Horſe Oƈtauius, and for that
I do appoint him ſtore of Prouender.
It is a Creature that I teach to ﬁght,
To winde, to ſtop, to run direƈtly on:
His corporall Motion, gouern’d by my Spirit,
And in ſome taſte, is Lepidus but ſo:
He muſt be taught, and train’d, and bid go forth:
A barren ſpirited Fellow; one that feeds
On Obieƈts, Arts, and Imitations.
Which out of vſe, and ſtal’de by other men
Begin his faſhion. Do not talke of him,
But as a property: and now Oƈtauius,
Liſten great things. Brutus and Caſſius
Are leuying Powers; We muſt ſtraight make head:
Therefore let our Alliance be combin’d,
Our beſt Friends made, our meanes ſtretcht,
And let vs preſently go ſit in Councell,
How couert matters may be beſt diſclos’d,
And open Perils ſureſt anſwered.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Let vs do ſo: for we are at the ſtake,
And bayed about with many Enemies,
And ſome that ſmile haue in their hearts I feare
Millions of Miſcheefes.

scene.stagedir: Drum. Enter Brutus, Lucillius, and the Army. Titinius and Pindarus meete them.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Stand ho.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: Giue the word ho, and Stand.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: What now Lucillius, is Caſſius neere?

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come
To do you ſalutation from his Maſter.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He greets me well. Your Maſter Pindarus
In his owne change, or by ill Oﬀicers,
Hath giuen me ſome worthy cauſe to wiſh
Things done, vndone: But if he be at hand
I ſhall be ſatisﬁed.

speech.speaker: Pin.
speech.line: I do not doubt
But that my Noble Maſter will appeare
Such as he is, full of regard, and Honour.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He is not doubted. A word Lucillius
How he receiu’d you: let me be reſolu’d.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: With courteſie, and with reſpeƈt enough,
But not with ſuch familiar inſtances,
Nor with ſuch free and friendly Conference
As he hath vs’d of old.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Thou haſt deſcrib’d
A hot Friend, cooling: Euer note Lucillius,
When Loue begins to ſicken and decay
It vſeth an enforced Ceremony.
There are no trickes, in plaine and ſimple Faith:
But hollow men, like Horſes hot at hand,
Make gallant ſhew, and promiſe of their Mettle:
But when they ſhould endure the bloody Spurre,
They fall their Creſts, and like deceitfull Iades
Sinke in the Triall. Comes his Army on?

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: They meane this night in Sardis to be quarter’d:
The greater part, the Horſe in generall
Are come with Caſſius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Hearke, he is arriu’d:
March gently on to meete him.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Stand ho.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Stand ho, ſpeake the word along.
Stand.
Stand.
Stand.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Brother, you haue done me wrong.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Iudge me you Gods; wrong I mine Enemies?
And if not ſo, how ſhould I wrong a Brother.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Brutus, this ſober forme of yours, hides wrongs,
And when you do them —

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Caſſius, be content,
Speake your greefes ſoftly, I do know you well.
Before the eyes of both our Armies heere
(Which ſhould perceiue nothing but Loue from vs)
Let vs not wrangle. Bid them moue away:
Then in my Tent Caſſius enlarge your Greefes,
And I will giue you Audience.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Pindarus,
Bid our Commanders leade their Charges oﬀ
A little from this ground.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Lucillius, do you the like, and let no man
Come to our Tent, till we haue done our Conference.
Let Lucius and Titinius guard our doore.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: That you haue wrong’d me, doth appear in this:
You haue condemn’d, and noted Lucius Pella
For taking Bribes heere of the Sardians;
Wherein my Letters, praying on his ſide,
Becauſe I knew the man was ſlighted oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You wrong’d your ſelfe to write in ſuch a caſe.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: In ſuch a time as this, it is not meet
That euery nice oﬀence ſhould beare his Comment.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Let me tell you Caſſius, you your ſelfe
Are much condemn’d to haue an itching Palme,
To ſell, and Mart your Oﬃces for Gold
To Vndeſeruers.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I, an itching Palme?
You know that you are Brutus that ſpeakes this,
Or by the Gods, this ſpeech were elſe your laſt.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: The name of Caſſius Honors this corruption,
And Chaſticement doth therefore hide his head.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Chaſticement?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Remember March, the Ides of March remēber:
Did not great Iulius bleede for Iuſtice ſake?
What Villaine touch’d his body, that did ſtab,
And not for Iuſtice? What? Shall one of Vs,
That ſtrucke the Formoſt man of all this World,
But for ſupporting Robbers: ſhall we now,
Contaminate our ﬁngers, with baſe Bribes?
And ſell the mighty ſpace of our large Honors
For ſo much traſh, as may be graſped thus?
I had rather be a Dogge, and bay the Moone,
Then ſuch a Roman.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Brutus, baite not me,
Ile not indure it: you forget your ſelfe
To hedge me in. I am a Souldier, I,
Older in praƈtice, Abler then your ſelfe
To make Conditions.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Go too: you are not Caſſius.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I am.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I ſay, you are not.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Vrge me no more, I ſhall forget my ſelfe:
Haue minde vpon your health: Tempt me no farther.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Away ſlight man.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Is’t poſſible?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Heare me, for I will ſpeake.
Muſt I giue way, and roome to your raſh Choller?
Shall I be frighted, when a Madman ſtares?

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: O ye Gods, ye Gods, Muſt I endure all this?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: All this? I more: Fret till your proud hart break.
Go ſhew your Slaues how Chollericke you are,
And make your Bondmen tremble. Muſt I bouge?
Muſt I obſerue you? Muſt I ſtand and crouch
Vnder your Teſtie Humour? By the Gods,
You ſhall digeſt the Venom of your Spleene
Though it do Split you. For, from this day forth,
Ile vſe you for my Mirth, yea for my Laughter
When you are Waſpiſh.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Is it come to this?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You ſay, you are a better Souldier:
Let it appeare ſo; make your vaunting true,
And it ſhall pleaſe me well. For mine owne part,
I ſhall be glad to learne of Noble men.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: You wrong me euery way:
You wrong me Brutus:
I ſaide, an Elder Souldier, not a Better.
Did I ſay Better?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: If you did, I care not.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: When Cæſar liu’d, he durſt not thus haue mou’d me.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Peace, peace, you durſt not ſo haue tempted him.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I durſt not.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: What? durſt not tempt him?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: For your life you durſt not.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Do not preſume too much vpon my Loue,
I may do that I ſhall be ſorry for.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You haue done that you ſhould be ſorry for.
There is no terror Caſſius in your threats:
For I am Arm’d ſo ſtrong in Honeſty,
That they paſſe by me, as the idle winde,
Which I reſpeƈt not. I did ſend to you
For certaine ſummes of Gold, which you deny’d me,
For I can raiſe no money by vile meanes:
By Heauen, I had rather Coine my Heart,
And drop my blood for Drachmaes, then to wring
From the hard hands of Peazants, their vile traſh
By any indireƈtion. I did ſend
To you for Gold to pay my Legions,
Which you deny’d me: was that done like Caſſius?
Should I haue anſwer’d Caius Caſſius ſo?
When Marcus Brutus growes ſo Couetous,
To locke ſuch Raſcall Counters from his Friends,
Be ready Gods with all your Thunder-bolts,
Daſh him to peeces.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I deny’d you not.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: You did.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I did not. He was but a Foole
That brought my anſwer back. Brutus hath riu’d my hart:
A Friend ſhould beare his Friends inﬁrmities;
But Brutus makes mine greater then they are.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I do not, till you praƈtice them on me.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: You loue me not.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I do not like your faults.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: A friendly eye could neuer ſee ſuch faults.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: A Flatterers would not, though they do appeare
As huge as high Olympus.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Come Antony, and yong Oƈtauius come,
Reuenge your ſelues alone on Caſſius,
For Caſſius is a-weary of the World:
Hated by one he loues, brau’d by his Brother,
Check’d like a bondman, all his faults obſeru’d,
Set in a Note-booke, learn’d, and con’d by roate
To caſt into my Teeth. O I could weepe
My Spirit from mine eyes. There is my Dagger,
And heere my naked Breaſt: Within, a Heart
Deerer then Pluto’s Mine, Richer then Gold:
If that thou bee’ſt a Roman, take it foorth.
I that deny’d thee Gold, will giue my Heart:
Strike as thou did’ſt at Cæſar: For I know,
When thou did’ſt hate him worſt, ӳ loued’ſt him better
Then euer thou loued’ſt Caſſius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Sheath your Dagger:
Be angry when you will, it ſhall haue ſcope:
Do what you will, Diſhonor, ſhall be Humour.
O Caſſius, you are yoaked with a Lambe
That carries Anger, as the Flint beares ﬁre,
Who much inforced, ſhewes a haſtie Sparke,
And ſtraite is cold agen.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Hath Caſſius liu’d
To be but Mirth and Laughter to his Brutus,
When greefe and blood ill temper’d, vexeth him?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: When I ſpoke that, I was ill temper’d too.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Do you confeſſe ſo much? Giue me your hand.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: And my heart too.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: O Brutus!

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Haue not you loue enough to beare with me,
When that raſh humour which my Mother gaue me
Makes me forgetfull.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Yes Caſsius, and from henceforth
When you are ouer-earneſt with your Brutus,
Hee’l thinke your Mother chides, and leaue you ſo.

speech.speaker: Poet.
speech.line: Let me go in to ſee the Generals,
There is ſome grudge betweene ’em, ’tis not meete
They be alone.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: You ſhall not come to them.

speech.speaker: Poet.
speech.line: Nothing but death ſhall ſtay me.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: How now? What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Poet.
speech.line: For ſhame you Generals; what do you meane?
Loue, and be Friends, as two ſuch men ſhould bee,
For I haue ſeene more yeeres I’me ſure then yee.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Ha, ha, how vildely doth this Cynicke rime?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Get you hence ſirra: Sawcy Fellow, hence.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Beare with him Brutus, ’tis his faſhion.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Ile know his humor, when he knowes his time:
What ſhould the Warres do with theſe Iigging Fooles?
Companion, hence.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Away, away be gone.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Lucillius and Titinius bid the Commanders
Prepare to lodge their Companies to night.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: And come your ſelues, & bring Meſſala with you
Immediately to vs.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Lucius, a bowle of Wine.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: I did not thinke you could haue bin ſo angry.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: O Caſſius, I am ſicke of many greefes.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Of your Philoſophy you make no vſe,
If you giue place to accidentall euils.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: No man beares ſorrow better. Portia is dead.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: Ha? Portia?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: She is dead.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: How ſcap’d I killing, when I croſt you ſo?
O inſupportable, and touching loſſe!
Vpon what ſickneſſe?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Impatient of my abſence,
And greefe, that yong Oƈtauius with Mark Antony
Haue made themſelues ſo ſtrong: For with her death
That tydings came. With this ſhe fell diſtraƈt,
And (her Attendants abſent) ſwallow’d ﬁre.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: And dy’d ſo?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Euen ſo.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: O ye immortall Gods!

scene.stagedir: Enter Boy with Wine, and Tapers.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Speak no more of her: Giue me a bowl of wine,
In this I bury all vnkindneſſe Caſsius.

speech.speaker: Caſ.
speech.line: My heart is thirſty for that Noble pledge.
Fill Lucius, till the Wine ore-ſwell the Cup:
I cannot drinke too much of Brutus loue.

speech.speaker: Brutus.
speech.line: Come in Titinius:
Welcome good Meſſala:
Now ſit we cloſe about this Taper heere,
And call in queſtion our neceſſities.

speech.speaker: Caſſ.
speech.line: Portia, art thou gone?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: No more I pray you.
Meſſala, I haue heere receiued Letters,
That yong Oƈtauius, and Marke Antony
Come downe vpon vs with a mighty power,
Bending their Expedition toward Philippi.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My ſelfe haue Letters of the ſelfe-ſame Tenure.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: With what Addition.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: That by proſcription, and billes of Outlarie,
Oƈtauius, Antony, and Lepidus,
Haue put to death, an hundred Senators.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Therein our Letters do not well agree:
Mine ſpeake of ſeuenty Senators, that dy’de
By their proſcriptions, Cicero being one.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Cicero one?

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Cicero is dead, and by that order of proſcription
Had you your Letters from your wife, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: No Meſſala.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Nor nothing in your Letters writ of her?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Nothing Meſſala.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: That me thinkes is ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Why aske you?
Heare you ought of her, in yours?

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: No my Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Now as you are a Roman tell me true.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Then like a Roman, beare the truth I tell,
For certaine ſhe is dead, and by ſtrange manner.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Why farewell Portia: We muſt die Meſſala:
With meditating that ſhe muſt dye once,
I haue the patience to endure it now.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Euen ſo great men, great loſſes ſhold indure.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I haue as much of this in Art as you,
But yet my Nature could not beare it ſo.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Well, to our worke aliue. What do you thinke
Of marching to Philippi preſently.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I do not thinke it good.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Your reaſon?

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: This it is:
’Tis better that the Enemie ſeeke vs,
So ſhall he waſte his meanes, weary his Souldiers,
Doing himſelfe oﬀence, whil’ſt we lying ſtill,
Are full of reſt, defence, and nimbleneſſe.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Good reaſons muſt of force giue place to better:
The people ’twixt Philippi, and this ground
Do ſtand but in a forc’d aﬀeƈtion:
For they haue grug’d vs Contribution.
The Enemy, marching along by them,
By them ſhall make a fuller number vp,
Come on refreſht, new added, and encourag’d:
From which aduantage ſhall we cut him oﬀ.
If at Philippi we do face him there,
Theſe people at our backe.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Heare me good Brother.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Vnder your pardon. You muſt note beſide,
That we haue tride the vtmoſt of our Friends:
Our Legions are brim full, our cauſe is ripe,
The Enemy encreaſeth euery day,
We at the height, are readie to decline.
There is a Tide in the aﬀayres of men,
Which taken at the Flood, leades on to Fortune:
Omitted, all the voyage of their life,
Is bound in Shallowes, and in Miſeries.
On ſuch a full Sea are we now a-ﬂoat,
And we muſt take the current when it ſerues,
Or looſe our Ventures.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Then with your will go on: wee’l along
Our ſelues, and meet them at Philippi.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: The deepe of night is crept vpon our talke,
And Nature muſt obey Neceſſitie,
Which we will niggard with a little reſt:
There is no more to ſay.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: No more, good night,
Early to morrow will we riſe, and hence.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Lucius my Gowne: farewell good Meſſala,
Good night Titinius: Noble, Noble Caſſius,
Good night, and good repoſe.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: O my deere Brother:
This was an ill beginning of the night:
Neuer come ſuch diuiſion ’tweene our ſoules:
Let it not Brutus.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Euery thing is well.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Good night my Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Good night good Brother.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Meſſa. Good night Lord Brutus.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Farwell euery one.
Giue me the Gowne. Where is thy Inſtrument?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Heere in the Tent.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: What, thou ſpeak’ſt drowſily?
Poore knaue I blame thee not, thou art ore-watch’d.
Call Claudio, and ſome other of my men,
Ile haue them ſleepe on Cuſhions in my Tent.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Varrus, and Claudio.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: Cals my Lord?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I pray you ſirs, lye in my Tent and ſleepe,
It may be I ſhall raiſe you by and by
On buſineſſe to my Brother Caſſius.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: So pleaſe you, we will ſtand,
And watch your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I will it not haue it ſo: Lye downe good ſirs,
It may be I ſhall otherwiſe bethinke me.
Looke Lucius, heere’s the booke I ſought for ſo:
I put it in the pocket of my Gowne.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I was ſure your Lordſhip did not giue it me.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Beare with me good Boy, I am much forgetfull.
Canſt thou hold vp thy heauie eyes a-while,
And touch thy Inſtrument a ſtraine or two.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I my Lord, an’t pleaſe you.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: It does my Boy:
I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: It is my duty Sir.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: I ſhould not vrge thy duty paſt thy might,
I know yong bloods looke for a time of reſt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I haue ſlept my Lord already.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: It was well done, and thou ſhalt ſleepe againe:
I will not hold thee long. If I do liue,
I will be good to thee.
This is a ſleepy Tune: O Murd’rous ſlumber!
Layeſt thou thy Leaden Mace vpon my Boy,
That playes thee Muſicke? Gentle knaue good night:
I will not do thee ſo much wrong to wake thee:
If thou do’ſt nod, thou break’ſt thy Inſtrument,
Ile take it from thee, and (good Boy) good night.
Let me ſee, let me ſee; is not the Leafe turn’d downe
Where I left reading? Heere it is I thinke.
How ill this Taper burnes. Ha! Who comes heere?
I thinke it is the weakeneſſe of mine eyes
That ſhapes this monſtrous Apparition.
It comes vpon me: Art thou any thing?
Art thou ſome God, ſome Angell, or ſome Diuell,
That mak’ſt my blood cold, and my haire to ſtare?
Speake to me, what thou art.

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: Thy euill Spirit Brutus?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Why com’ſt thou?

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: To tell thee thou ſhalt ſee me at Philippi.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Well: then I ſhall ſee thee againe?

speech.speaker: Ghoſt.
speech.line: I, at Philippi.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Why I will ſee thee at Philippi then:
Now I haue taken heart, thou vaniſheſt.
Ill Spirit, I would hold more talke with thee.
Boy, Lucius, Varrus, Claudio, Sirs: Awake:
Claudio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: The ſtrings my Lord, are falſe.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: He thinkes he ſtill is at his Inſtrument.
Lucius, awake.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Did’ſt thou dreame Lucius, that thou ſo cryedſt
out?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord, I do not know that I did cry.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Yes that thou did’ſt: Did’ſt thou ſee any thing?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Nothing my Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Sleepe againe Lucius: Sirra Claudio, Fellow,
Thou: Awake.

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Why did you ſo cry out ſirs, in your ſleepe?

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: Did we my Lord?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: I: ſaw you any thing?

speech.speaker: Var.
speech.line: No my Lord, I ſaw nothing.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Nor I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Go, and commend me to my Brother Caſſius:
Bid him ſet on his Powres betimes before,
And we will follow.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: It ſhall be done my Lord.

scene.stagedir: Enter Oƈtauius, Antony, and their Army.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Now Antony, our hopes are anſwered,
You ſaid the Enemy would not come downe,
But keepe the Hilles and vpper Regions:
It proues not ſo: their battailes are at hand,
They meane to warne vs at Philippi heere:
Anſwering before we do demand of them.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Tut I am in their boſomes, and I know
Wherefore they do it: They could be content
To viſit other places, and come downe
With fearefull brauery: thinking by this face
To faſten in our thoughts that they haue Courage;
But ’tis not ſo.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: Prepare you Generals,
The Enemy comes on in gallant ſhew:
Their bloody ſigne of Battell is hung out,
And ſomething to be done immediately.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oƈtauius, leade your Battaile ſoftly on
Vpon the left hand of the euen Field.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Vpon the right hand I, keepe thou the left.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why do you croſſe me in this exigent.

speech.speaker: Oƈta
speech.line: I do not croſſe you: but I will do ſo.

scene.stagedir: Drum. Enter Brutus, Caſſius, & their Army.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: They ſtand, and would haue parley.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Stand faſt Titinius, we muſt out and talke.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Mark Antony, ſhall we giue ſigne of Battaile?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: No Cæſar, we will anſwer on their Charge.
Make forth, the Generals would haue ſome words.

speech.speaker: Oƈt.
speech.line: Stirre not vntill the Signall.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Words before blowes: is it ſo Countrymen?

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Not that we loue words better, as you do.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Good words are better then bad ſtrokes Oƈtauius.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: In your bad ſtrokes Brutus, you giue good words
Witneſſe the hole you made in Cæſars heart,
Crying long liue, Haile Cæſar.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Antony,
The poſture of your blowes are yet vnknowne;
But for your words, they rob the Hibla Bees,
And leaue them Hony-leſſe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Not ſtingleſſe too.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: O yes, and ſoundleſſe too:
For you haue ſtolne their buzzing Antony,
And very wiſely threat before you ſting.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Villains: you did not ſo, when your vile daggers
Hackt one another in the ſides of Cæſar:
You ſhew’d your teethes like Apes,
And fawn’d like Hounds,
And bow’d like Bondmen, kiſſing Cæſars feete;
Whil’ſt damned Caska, like a Curre, behinde
Strooke Cæſar on the necke. O you Flatterers.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Flatterers? Now Brutus thanke your ſelfe,
This tongue had not oﬀended ſo to day.
If Caſſius might haue rul’d.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Come, come, the cauſe. If arguing make vs ſwet,
The proofe of it will turne to redder drops:
Looke, I draw a Sword againſt Conſpirators,
When thinke you that the Sword goes vp againe?
Neuer till Cæſars three and thirtie wounds
Be well aueng’d; or till another Cæſar
Haue added ſlaughter to the Sword of Traitors.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Cæſar, thou canſt not dye by Traitors hands.
Vnleſſe thou bring’ſt them with thee.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: So I hope:
I was not borne to dye on Brutus Sword.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: O if thou wer’t the Nobleſt of thy Straine,
Yong-man, thou could’ſt not dye more honourable.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: A peeuiſh School-boy, worthles of ſuch Honor
Ioyn’d with a Masker, and a Reueller.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Old Caſſius ſtill.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Come Antony: away:
Deﬁance Traitors, hurle we in your teeth.
If you dare ﬁght to day, come to the Field;
If not, when you haue ſtomackes.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Why now blow winde, ſwell Billow,
And ſwimme Barke:
The Storme is vp, and all is on the hazard.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Ho Lucillius, hearke, a word with you.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Meſſala.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: What ſayes my Generall?

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Meſſala, this is my Birth-day: at this very day
Was Caſſius borne. Giue me thy hand Meſſala:
Be thou my witneſſe, that againſt my will
(As Pompey was) am I compell’d to ſet
Vpon one Battell all our Liberties.
You know, that I held Epicurus ſtrong,
And his Opinion: Now I change my minde,
And partly credit things that do preſage.
Comming from Sardis, on our former Enſigne
Two mighty Eagles fell, and there they pearch’d,
Gorging and feeding from our Soldiers hands,
Who to Philippi heere conſorted vs:
This Morning are they ﬂed away, and gone,
And in their ſteeds, do Rauens, Crowes, and Kites
Fly ore our heads, and downward looke on vs
As we were ſickely prey; their ſhadowes ſeeme
A Canopy moſt fatall, vnder which
Our Army lies, ready to giue vp the Ghoſt.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Beleeue not ſo.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: I but beleeue it partly,
For I am freſh of ſpirit, and reſolu’d
To meete all perils, very conſtantly.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Euen ſo Lucillius.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Now moſt Noble Brutus,
The Gods to day ſtand friendly, that we may
Louers in peace, leade on our dayes to age.
But ſince the aﬀayres of men reſts ſtill incertaine,
Let’s reaſon with the worſt that may befall.
If we do loſe this Battaile, then is this
The very laſt time we ſhall ſpeake together:
What are you then determined to do?

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Euen by the rule of that Philoſophy,
By which I did blame Cato, for the death
Which he did giue himſelfe, I know not how:
But I do ﬁnde it Cowardly, and vile,
For feare of what might fall, ſo to preuent
The time of life, arming my ſelfe with patience,
To ſtay the prouidence of ſome high Powers,
That gouerne vs below.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Then, if we looſe this Battaile,
You are contented to be led in Triumph
Thorow the ſtreets of Rome.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: No Caſſius, no:
Thinke not thou Noble Romane,
That euer Brutus will go bound to Rome,
He beares too great a minde. But this ſame day
Muſt end that worke, the Ides of March begun.
And whether we ſhall meete againe, I know not:
Therefore our euerlaſting farewell take:
For euer, and for euer, farewell Caſſius,
If we do meete againe, why we ſhall ſmile;
If not, why then this parting was well made.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: For euer, and for euer, farewell Brutus:
If we do meete againe, wee’l ſmile indeede;
If not, ’tis true, this parting was well made.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Why then leade on. O that a man might know
The end of this dayes buſineſſe, ere it come:
But it ſufﬁceth, that the day will end,
And then the end is knowne. Come ho, away.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Ride, ride Meſſala, ride and giue theſe Billes
Vnto the Legions, on the other ſide.
Let them ſet on at once: for I perceiue
But cold demeanor in Oƈtauio’s wing:
And ſodaine puſh giues them the ouerthrow:
Ride, ride Meſſala, let them all come downe.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: O looke Titinius, looke, the Villaines ﬂye:
My ſelfe haue to mine owne turn’d Enemy:
This Enſigne heere of mine was turning backe,
I ſlew the Coward, and did take it from him.

speech.speaker: Titin.
speech.line: O Caſſius, Brutus gaue the word too early,
Who hauing ſome aduantage on Oƈtauius,
Tooke it too eagerly: his Soldiers fell to ſpoyle,
Whilſt we by Antony are all inclos’d.

speech.speaker: Pind.
speech.line: Fly further oﬀ my Lord: ﬂye further oﬀ,
Mark Antony is in your Tents my Lord:
Flye therefore Noble Caſſius, ﬂye farre oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: This Hill is farre enough. Looke, look Titinius
Are thoſe my Tents where I perceiue the ﬁre?

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: They are, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Titinius, if thou loueſt me,
Mount thou my horſe, and hide thy ſpurres in him,
Till he haue brought thee vp to yonder Troopes
And heere againe, that I may reſt aſſur’d
Whether yond Troopes, are Friend or Enemy.

speech.speaker: Tit
speech.line: I will be heere againe, euen with a thought.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Go Pindarus, get higher on that hill,
My ſight was euer thicke: regard Titinius,
And tell me what thou not’ſt about the Field.
This day I breathed ﬁrſt, Time is come round,
And where I did begin, there ſhall I end,
My life is run his compaſſe. Sirra, what newes?

speech.speaker: Pind.
speech.line: Aboue. O my Lord.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: What newes?

speech.speaker: Pind.
speech.line: Titinius is encloſed round about
With Horſemen, that make to him on the Spurre,
Yet he ſpurres on. Now they are almoſt on him:
Now Titinius. Now ſome light: O he lights too.
Hee’s tane. Showt.
And hearke, they ſhout for ioy.

speech.speaker: Caſſi.
speech.line: Come downe, behold no more:
O Coward that I am, to liue ſo long,
To ſee my beſt Friend tane before my face
Come hither ſirrah: In Parthia did I take thee Priſoner,
And then I ſwore thee, ſauing of thy life,
That whatſoeuer I did bid thee do,
Thou ſhould’ſt attempt it. Come now, keepe thine oath,
Now be a Free-man, and with this good Sword
That ran through Cæſars bowels, ſearch this boſome.
Stand not to anſwer: Heere, take thou the Hilts,
And when my face is couer’d, as ’tis now,
Guide thou the Sword — Cæſar, thou art reueng’d,
Euen with the Sword that kill’d thee.

speech.speaker: Pin.
speech.line: So, I am free,
Yet would not ſo haue beene
Durſt I haue done my will. O Caſſius,
Farre from this Country Pindarus ſhall run,
Where neuer Roman ſhall take note of him.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: It is but change, Titinius: for Oƈtauius
Is ouerthrowne by Noble Brutus power,
As Caſſius Legions are by Antony.

speech.speaker: Titin.
speech.line: Theſe tydings will well comfort Caſſius.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Where did you leaue him.

speech.speaker: Titin.
speech.line: All diſconſolate,
With Pindarus his Bondman, on this Hill.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Is not that he that lyes vpon the ground?

speech.speaker: Titin.
speech.line: He lies not like the Liuing. O my heart!

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Is not that hee?

speech.speaker: Titin.
speech.line: No, this was he Meſſala,
But Caſſius is no more. O ſetting Sunne:
As in thy red Rayes thou doeſt ſinke to night;
So in his red blood Caſsius day is ſet.
The Sunne of Rome is ſet. Our day is gone,
Clowds, Dewes, and Dangers come; our deeds are done:
Miſtruſt of my ſucceſſe hath done this deed.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Miſtruſt of good ſucceſſe hath done this deed.
O hatefull Error, Melancholies Childe:
Why do’ſt thou ſhew to the apt thoughts of men
The things that are not? O Error ſoone conceyu’d,
Thou neuer com’ſt vnto a happy byrth,
But kil’ſt the Mother that engendred thee.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: What Pindarus? Where art thou Pindarus?

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Seeke him Titinius, whilſt I go to meet
The Noble Brutus, thruſting this report
Into his eares; I may ſay thruſting it:
For piercing Steele, and Darts inuenomed,
Shall be as welcome to the eares of Brutus,
As tydings of this ſight.

speech.speaker: Tit.
speech.line: Hye you Meſſala,
And I will ſeeke for Pindarus the while:
Why did’ſt thou ſend me forth braue Caſsius?
Did I not meet thy Friends, and did not they
Put on my Browes this wreath of Viƈtorie,
And bid me giue it thee? Did’ſt thou not heare their ſhowts?
Alas, thou haſt miſconſtrued euery thing.
But hold thee, take this Garland on thy Brow,
Thy Brutus bid me giue it thee, and I
Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,
And ſee how I regarded Caius Caſsius:
By your leaue Gods: This is a Romans part,
Come Caſsius Sword, and ﬁnde Titinius hart.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Meſſala, yong Cato, Strato, Volumnius, and Lucillius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Where, where Meſſala, doth his body lye?

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Loe yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Titinius face is vpward.

speech.speaker: Cato.
speech.line: He is ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: O Iulius Cæſar, thou art mighty yet,
Thy Spirit walkes abroad, and turnes our Swords
In our owne proper Entrailes.

speech.speaker: Cato.
speech.line: Braue Titinius,
Looke where he haue not crown’d dead Caſsius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Are yet two Romans liuing ſuch as theſe?
The laſt of all the Romans, far thee well:
It is impoſſible, that euer Rome
Should breed thy fellow. Friends I owe mo teares
To this dead man, then you ſhall ſee me pay.
I ſhall ﬁnde time, Caſsius: I ſhall ﬁnde time.
Come therefore, and to Tharſus ſend his body,
His Funerals ſhall not be in our Campe,
Leaſt it diſcomfort vs. Lucillius come,
And come yong Cato, let vs to the Field,
Labio and Flauio ſet our Battailes on:
’Tis three a clocke, and Romans yet ere night,
We ſhall try Fortune in a ſecond ﬁght.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter Brutus, Meſſala, Cato, Lucillius, and Flauius.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Yet Country-men: O yet, hold vp your heads.

speech.speaker: Cato.
speech.line: What Baſtard doth not? Who will go with me?
I will proclaime my name about the Field.
I am the Sonne of Marcus Cato, hoe.
A Foe to Tyrants, and my Countries Friend.
I am the Sonne of Marcus Cato, hoe.
And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I,
Brutus my Countries Friend: Know me for Brutus.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: O yong and Noble Cato, art thou downe?
Why now thou dyeſt, as brauely as Titinius,
And may’ſt be honour’d, being Cato’s Sonne.

speech.speaker: Sold.
speech.line: Yeeld, or thou dyeſt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Onely I yeeld to dye:
There is ſo much, that thou wilt kill me ſtraight:
Kill Brutus, and be honour’d in his death.

speech.speaker: Sold.
speech.line: We muſt not: a Noble Priſoner.

speech.speaker: 2. Sold.
speech.line: Roome hoe: tell Antony, Brutus is tane.

speech.speaker: 1. Sold.
speech.line: Ile tell thee newes. Heere comes the Generall,
Brutus is tane, Brutus is tane my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where is hee?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Safe Antony, Brutus is ſafe enough:
I dare aſſure thee, that no Enemy
Shall euer take aliue the Noble Brutus:
The Gods defend him from ſo great a ſhame,
When you do ﬁnde him, or aliue, or dead,
He will be found like Brutus, like himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: This is not Brutus friend, but I aſſure you,
A prize no leſſe in worth; keepe this man ſafe,
Giue him all kindneſſe. I had rather haue
Such men my Friends, then Enemies. Go on,
And ſee where Brutus be aliue or dead,
And bring vs word, vnto Oƈtauius Tent:
How euery thing is chanc’d.

scene.stagedir: Enter Brutus, Dardanius, Clitus, Strato, and Volumnius.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Come poore remaines of friends, reſt on this
Rocke.

speech.speaker: Clit.
speech.line: Statillius ſhew’d the Torch-light, but my Lord
He came not backe: he is or tane, or ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Sit thee downe, Clitus: ſlaying is the word,
It is a deed in faſhion. Hearke thee, Clitus.

speech.speaker: Clit.
speech.line: What I, my Lord? No, not for all the World.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Peace then, no words.

speech.speaker: Clit.
speech.line: Ile rather kill my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Hearke thee, Dardanius.

speech.speaker: Dard.
speech.line: Shall I doe ſuch a deed?

speech.speaker: Clit.
speech.line: O Dardanius.

speech.speaker: Dard.
speech.line: O Clitus.

speech.speaker: Clit.
speech.line: What ill requeſt did Brutus make to thee?

speech.speaker: Dard.
speech.line: To kill him, Clitus: looke he meditates.

speech.speaker: Clit.
speech.line: Now is that Noble Veſſell full of griefe,
That it runnes ouer euen at his eyes.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Come hither, good Volumnius, list a word.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: What ſayes my Lord?

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Why this, Volumnius:
The Ghoſt of Cæſar hath appear’d to me
Two ſeuerall times by Night: at Sardis, once;
And this laſt Night, here in Philippi ﬁelds:
I know my houre is come.

speech.speaker: Volum.
speech.line: Not ſo, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Brut.
speech.line: Nay, I am ſure it is, Volumnius.
Thou ſeeſt the World, Volumnius, how it goes,
Our Enemies haue beat vs to the Pit:
It is more worthy, to leape in our ſelues,
Then tarry till they puſh vs. Good Volumnius,
Thou know’ſt, that we two went to Schoole together:
Euen for that our loue of old, I prethee
Hold thou my Sword Hilts, whileſt I runne on it.

speech.speaker: Vol.
speech.line: That’s not an Oﬀice for a friend, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cly.
speech.line: Fly, ﬂye my Lord, there is no tarrying heere.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Farewell to you, and you, and Volumnius.
Strato, thou haſt bin all this while aſleepe:
Farewell to thee, to Strato, Countrymen:
My heart doth ioy, that yet in all my life,
I found no man, but he was true to me.
I ſhall haue glory by this looſing day
More then Oƈtauius, and Marke Antony,
By this vile Conqueſt ſhall attaine vnto.
So fare you well at once, for Brutus tongue
Hath almoſt ended his liues History:
Night hangs vpon mine eyes, my Bones would reſt,
That haue but labour’d, to attaine this houre.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Cry within, Flye, ﬂye, ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Cly.
speech.line: Fly my Lord, ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Hence: I will follow:
I prythee Strato, ſtay thou by thy Lord,
Thou art a Fellow of a good reſpeƈt:
Thy life hath had ſome ſmatch of Honor in it,
Hold then my Sword, and turne away thy face,
While I do run vpon it. Wilt thou Strato?

speech.speaker: Stra.
speech.line: Giue me your hand ﬁrſt. Fare you wel my Lord.

speech.speaker: Bru.
speech.line: Farewell good Strato. — Cæſar, now be ſtill,
I kill’d not thee with halfe ſo good a will.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Oƈtauius, Meſſala, Lucillius, and the Army.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: What man is that?

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: My Maſters man. Strato, where is thy Maſter?

speech.speaker: Stra.
speech.line: Free from the Bondage you are in Meſſala,
The Conquerors can but make a ﬁre of him:
For Brutus onely ouercame himſelfe,
And no man elſe hath Honor by his death.

speech.speaker: Lucil.
speech.line: So Brutus ſhould be found. I thank thee Brutus
That thou haſt prou’d Lucillius ſaying true,

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: All that ſeru’d Brutus, I will entertaine them.
Fellow, wilt thou beſtow thy time with me?

speech.speaker: Stra.
speech.line: I, if Meſſala will preferre me to you.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: Do ſo, good Meſſala.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: How dyed my Maſter Strato?

speech.speaker: Stra.
speech.line: I held the Sword, and he did run on it.

speech.speaker: Meſſa.
speech.line: Oƈtauius, then take him to follow thee,
That did the lateſt ſeruice to my Maſter.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: This was the Nobleſt Roman of them all:
All the Conſpirators ſaue onely hee,
Did that they did, in enuy of great Cæſar:
He, onely in a generall honeſt thought,
And common good to all, made one of them.
His life was gentle, and the Elements
So mixt in him, that Nature might ſtand vp,
And ſay to all the world; This was a man.

speech.speaker: Oƈta.
speech.line: According to his Vertue, let vs vſe him
Withall Reſpeƈt, and Rites of Buriall.
Within my Tent his bones to night ſhall ly,
Moſt like a Souldier ordered Honourably:
So call the Field to reſt, and let’s away,
To part the glories of this happy day.
